doc_id=1052 igt_id=igt1052-333 15718 15727 L+CR L+CR L L+CR L+CR L B T T T
language: German (deu)
line=15718 tag=L+CR:        Eine adversative Konstruktion setzt zunachst Alternativen, also schwachen Kontrast
line=15719 tag=L+CR:                                                        ¨
line=15720 tag=L:        voraus. Der Kontrast im Sinne von Adversativitat liegt darin, dass die gleichzeitige
line=15721 tag=L+CR:        Geltung der Alternativen (in bezug auf den im ersten Konnekt etablierten Hinter-
line=15722 tag=L+CR:                  ¨
line=15723 tag=L:        grund) zuruckgewiesen wird.
line=15724 tag=B:
line=15725 tag=T:        An adversative construction requires, firstly, alternatives, that is to say, a weak contrast.
line=15726 tag=T:        Contrast in the sense of adversativity consists in the rejection of the simultaneous validity
line=15727 tag=T:        of the two alternatives (with respect to the background established in the first conjunct).

line=830 tag=T:                 know or care about what it was.'

language: German (deu)
line=912 tag=L:  (16)    Mary musste irgendeinen Arzt         heiraten.
line=913 tag=G:          Mary had to irgend-one doctor marry.
line=914 tag=T+EX:  (a)     Wide-scope: There was some doctor Mary had to marry - the speaker doesn't
line=915 tag=T:          know who it was.
line=916 tag=T+AL+EX:  (b)     Narrow-scope: Mary had to marry some doctor or other - any doctor was a
line=917 tag=T+AL:          permitted option.

doc_id=1753 igt_id=igt1753-65 778 796 L+CR+SY L+CR+SY B B M M M M M M M M B M B G L G T
language: German (deu)
line=778 tag=L+CR+SY:         b. *[CP1 Wasj            hast du         NICHT tj    gesagt, [           wiei    sie ti
line=779 tag=L+CR+SY:                                                                           CP2
line=780 tag=B:
line=781 tag=B:
line=782 tag=M:    11
line=783 tag=M:        Rizzi (1994) follows McDaniel (1989) in claiming that the non-contentive WH element and the
line=784 tag=M:  contentive WH phrase in intermediate Spec-CP form an S-stru cture chain. Thus, on this account, the non-
line=785 tag=M:  contentive WH element is base-generated in matrix Spec-CP and is connected to the contentive WH
line=786 tag=M:  phrase directly. However, there is evidence that non -contentive WH elements originate from an underlying
line=787 tag=M:  Case position, and are connected to the contentive WH phrase indirectly rather than directly (cf. Horvath
line=788 tag=M:  1997). This is why I choose to indicate that the non -contentive WH element has moved in the examples I
line=789 tag=M:  introduce.
line=790 tag=B:
line=791 tag=M:  338   Eric Mathieu
line=792 tag=B:
line=793 tag=G:                      WH         have you not               said         how she
line=794 tag=L:                      geschlafen       hat]]?
line=795 tag=G:                      slept            has
line=796 tag=T:                      `How did you not say that she slept?'

doc_id=1753 igt_id=igt1753-66 797 803 L+CR+SY L+CR+SY G+SY L+SY G T M+AC
language: German (deu)
line=797 tag=L+CR+SY:        c. *[         Wasj       hast du      NICHT tj      gesagt, [CP2 warumi
line=798 tag=L+CR+SY:                CP1
line=799 tag=G+SY:                      WH         have you not               said         why
line=800 tag=L+SY:                      sie ti     nicht kommt]]?
line=801 tag=G:                      she        not comes
line=802 tag=T:                      `Why did you not say that she does not come?'
line=803 tag=M+AC:                      (Rizzi 1994:369)

doc_id=1795 igt_id=igt1795-1 12 15 M+CN+EX L G T
language: German (deu)
line=12 tag=M+CN+EX:     · Examples of AcI (`Accusativus cum Infinitivo')-constructions:
line=13 tag=L:      (1)   a. Die Studenten hören [AcIden Professor reden].
line=14 tag=G:               the students          hear      the professor (ACC) talk (INF)
line=15 tag=T:               `The students hear the professor talk.'

doc_id=1795 igt_id=igt1795-2 16 18 L G T
language: German (deu)
line=16 tag=L:            b. Der Professor lässt [AcIdie Studenten den Artikel zusammenfassen].
line=17 tag=G:               the professor        lets/has   the students (ACC) the article    summarize (     INF)
line=18 tag=T:               `The professor lets/has the students summarize the article.'

doc_id=1795 igt_id=igt1795-3 19 21 L G T
language: German (deu)
line=19 tag=L:            c. Das Kind lässt [AcIden Stein ins Wasser fallen].
line=20 tag=G:               the     child lets     the rock (ACC) into-the water fall (INF)
line=21 tag=T:              `The child lets the rock fall into the water.'

doc_id=1795 igt_id=igt1795-4 26 28 L G T
language: German (deu)
line=26 tag=L:      (2)   a. ..., dass die Studenten [AcIden Professor reden] hören.
line=27 tag=G:                       that the students             the professor    talk       hear
line=28 tag=T:               `...that the students hear the professor talk.'

doc_id=1795 igt_id=igt1795-5 30 32 L G T
language: German (deu)
line=30 tag=L:      (3)   a. ...dass die Studenten [den Professor zu verstehen] versuchen.
line=31 tag=G:                     that   the students       the    professor   to understand (   INF)   try
line=32 tag=T:               `...that the students try to understand the professor.'

doc_id=1795 igt_id=igt1795-6 43 45 L+SY G T
language: German (deu)
line=43 tag=L+SY:       (4)     Martini hört [AcIden Mannj über sichi/j/ihni/*j reden].
line=44 tag=G:                Martin hears       the man (ACC) about self/ him            talk
line=45 tag=T:               `Martin hears the man talk about himself/him.'

doc_id=1795 igt_id=igt1795-7 61 65 L+SY G+CR G+CR T M+AC
language: German (deu)
line=61 tag=L+SY:       (5)     a. Hansi lässt sichi/ihm*i einen Stein auf den Kopf fallen.
line=62 tag=G+CR:                   Hans lets self/him (DAT) a rock (              on     the head    fall
line=63 tag=G+CR:                                                          ACC)
line=64 tag=T:                  `Hans lets a rock fall on his head.'
line=65 tag=M+AC:                  (Frey 1993: 116)

line=67 tag=G:                   Hans lets        the rock (ACC) self/him (          on the head    fall
line=68 tag=G:                                                                DAT)
line=69 tag=T:                  `Hans lets a rock fall on his head.'

line=94 tag=T:               `The king has the prisoner kneel down before him.'

line=5361 tag=M+LN:           b.   German:
line=5362 tag=L:                Er ho te, da ihm geholfen wurde.
line=5363 tag=G:                he hoped, that he helped was
line=5364 tag=M:      4 In the current implementation two macros are used to identify the controller (#CON-
line=5365 tag=M:  TROLLER) and the controlled element (#CONTROLLEE). The de nition of these macros
line=5366 tag=M:  is given in (25).
line=5367 tag=M:      5 In a control structure only referential prop erties are controlled. This is what makes
line=5368 tag=M:  control structures di erent from raising constructions. Control structures are not the
line=5369 tag=M:  result of NP movement, since in a control structure both verbs, the matrix verb and
line=5370 tag=M:  the subordinate verb, assign thematic roles, so that the -Criterion would be violated
line=5371 tag=M:  if the NP was moved out of the subordinate clause into another -marked position (see
line=5372 tag=M:   van Riemskijk and Williams86]).
line=5373 tag=M:      6 Pragmatic control structures app ear in in nitival sub ject p ositions (e.g. PRO to leave
line=5374 tag=M:  would be nice) and in indirect questions (e.g.It is unknown to usi , what PROi to do).
line=5375 tag=B:
line=5376 tag=M:  9.5. CONTROL STRUCTURES                                                         99
line=5377 tag=B:
line=5378 tag=B:
line=5379 tag=T+EX:             `He hoped to be helped.'                                                   sub ject control

line=105 tag=M+AC:                                                                    (Staudacher, 2000: 195)

line=805 tag=G:       Mary must irgend-one man marry who irgend-where
line=806 tag=B:
line=807 tag=L:        in Bayern wohnt.

line=814 tag=M:        lives anywhere in Bavaria is a permitted marriage option for Mary).

doc_id=2654 igt_id=igt2654-5 181 191 L B M M M M M M M+EX M T
language: German (deu)
line=181 tag=L:  (3)      a. Er sei krank.
line=182 tag=B:
line=183 tag=M:       4 The Dutch use of zullen differs from the use in other Germanic languages as discussed in (2)
line=184 tag=M:  because only the past tense of zullen is evidential. Note that all examples of shall-cognates in (2) are
line=185 tag=M:  in the present tense. In these languages, both present and past tenses appear to be evidential. This
line=186 tag=M:  can be compared to the use of Dutch evidential moeten `must' which is also evidential in both the
line=187 tag=M:  present and past tense.
line=188 tag=M:
line=189 tag=M+EX:                           The Relation between Modality and Evidentiality                               5
line=190 tag=M:
line=191 tag=T:             `He is said to be ill.'

line=1872 tag=M:  The pronoun wer (who) does not appear in relative clauses that modify a noun.

line=149 tag=M:                                                                                                    emerge, such a construction must be unmarked under other aspects. As will be shown in
line=150 tag=M:                                                                      z    y t POSS(y,z)(t)
line=151 tag=L+DB:        Ich habe ein Fahrrad.       Das Fahrrad gehört mir.

doc_id=2832 igt_id=igt2832-4 156 157 T+DB L+DB
language: German (deu)
line=156 tag=T+DB:       The house has three bathrooms.    There are three bathrooms in the house.
line=157 tag=L+DB:       Das Haus hat drei Bäder.          In dem Haus sind drei Bäder.

doc_id=2832 igt_id=igt2832-6 181 185 M+CN+DB M L+DB M+DB T+DB+EX
language: German (deu)
line=181 tag=M+CN+DB:  (18) Verbs with copula reading :
line=182 tag=M:                                                                                                 Typical change of location verbs: throw, put, dip, splash, glue
line=183 tag=L+DB:       Hans liebte zu gärtnern.
line=184 tag=M+DB:                                                                                                 (25) a. He threw the book behind the tree.
line=185 tag=T+DB+EX:       `John liked to be a gardener.' (i.e., to behave temporarily like a gardener)

doc_id=2832 igt_id=igt2832-7 189 194 M+CN+DB M L+DB M M T+DB
language: German (deu)
line=189 tag=M+CN+DB:  (19) Vers with inchoative reading:                                                                                              P y x e {THROW(x,y) & P(y)}(e)
line=190 tag=M:                                                                                                       b. throw:
line=191 tag=L+DB:       Das Holzwerk splitterte.                                                                                                   u (BEC) LOC(u, BEHIND* the tree)
line=192 tag=M:                                                                                                          behind the tree:
line=193 tag=M:                                                    x e BEC SPLINTER(x)(e)
line=194 tag=T+DB:       The woodwork splintered.                                                                           throw behind the tree: y x e {THROW(x,y) & BEC LOC(y, BEH* the tree)}(e)

doc_id=2832 igt_id=igt2832-8 195 198 M+CN+DB L+DB G+DB T+DB+EX
language: German (deu)
line=195 tag=M+CN+DB:  (20) Verbs with causative reading:                                                             Locative alternation: The predicate LOC gets incorporated into the verb itself.
line=196 tag=L+DB:       Hans bündelte die Stöcke.                                                                 (26) a. Anna glued all the photos at the wall.
line=197 tag=G+DB:       John bundled the sticks.                                                                           Anna klebte all die Photos an die Wand.
line=198 tag=T+DB+EX:       `John made the sticks to be in a bundle.' y x e {ACT(x) & BEC BUNDLE(y)}(e)                        glue: P y x e {GLUE(x,y) & P(y)}(e)

language: German (deu)
line=205 tag=M+CN+DB:  (21) Location verbs:                                                                           these verbs have both options:
line=206 tag=L+DB:       a. Hans kellerte den Wein.                                                                (27) a. Anna schickte dem Verleger            die Photos.
line=207 tag=T+DB+EX:          John cellared the wine. = `John made the wine to be located in a cellar.'                                        the.DAT publisher the.ACC photos

line=1545 tag=M+DB:                                                                                 fact that two CPs are coordinated is, of course, quite unremarkable. Only
line=1546 tag=G+DB:          when somebody to house comes and there stands the
line=1547 tag=M+DB:                                                                                 one of the CPs contains the complementizer, in contrast to Höhle's analy-
line=1548 tag=L+DB+CR+SY:          Gerichtsvollzieher vor         der Tür tj

line=1553 tag=M+DB:                                                                                 conjuncts. First, it is often the case that subordinate clauses are intro -

doc_id=3134 igt_id=igt3134-1 12 15 M+CN L+SY G T
language: German (deu)
line=12 tag=M+CN:     · Examples of AcI (`Accusativus cum Infinitivo')-constructions:
line=13 tag=L+SY:      (1)   a. Die Studenten hören [AcIden Professor reden].
line=14 tag=G:               the students         hear       the professor (ACC) talk (INF)
line=15 tag=T:               `The students hear the professor talk.'

doc_id=3134 igt_id=igt3134-2 16 18 L+SY G T
language: German (deu)
line=16 tag=L+SY:            b. Der Professor lässt [AcIdie Studenten den Artikel zusammenfassen].
line=17 tag=G:               the professor        lets/has   the students (ACC) the article    summarize (     INF)
line=18 tag=T:               `The professor lets/has the students summarize the article.'

doc_id=3134 igt_id=igt3134-3 19 21 L+SY G T
language: German (deu)
line=19 tag=L+SY:            c. Das Kind lässt [AcIden Stein ins Wasser fallen].
line=20 tag=G:               the     child lets     the rock (ACC) into-the water fall (INF)
line=21 tag=T:              `The child lets the rock fall into the water.'

doc_id=3134 igt_id=igt3134-4 26 28 L+SY G T
language: German (deu)
line=26 tag=L+SY:      (2)   a. ..., dass die Studenten [AcIden Professor reden] hören.
line=27 tag=G:                       that the students             the professor    talk       hear
line=28 tag=T:               `...that the students hear the professor talk.'

doc_id=3134 igt_id=igt3134-5 30 32 L G T
language: German (deu)
line=30 tag=L:      (3)   a. ...dass die Studenten [den Professor zu verstehen] versuchen.
line=31 tag=G:                     that   the students       the    professor   to understand (   INF)   try
line=32 tag=T:               `...that the students try to understand the professor.'

doc_id=3134 igt_id=igt3134-6 43 45 L+SY G T
language: German (deu)
line=43 tag=L+SY:       (4)     Martini hört [AcIden Mannj über sichi/j/ihni/*j reden].
line=44 tag=G:                Martin hears       the man (ACC) about self/ him            talk
line=45 tag=T:               `Martin hears the man talk about himself/him.'

line=62 tag=G+CR:                   Hans lets self/him (DAT) a rock (              on     the head    fall
line=63 tag=G+CR:                                                          ACC)
line=64 tag=T:                  `Hans lets a rock fall on his head.'
line=65 tag=M+AC:                  (Frey 1993: 116)

line=68 tag=G+CR:                                                                DAT)

doc_id=3137 igt_id=igt3137-15 323 326 L L T T
language: German (deu)
line=323 tag=L:            (i)   Ein CFC ist die minimale abschießende Kategorie, in der sämtliche Elemente, die durch einen gegebenen
line=324 tag=L:                   lexikalischen Kopf eine Projektionslizenz erhalten, realisiert sind.
line=325 tag=T:                  `A CFC is the minimal domain-closing category in which all the elements that get a license to project from a given
line=326 tag=T:                  lexical head are realized.'

doc_id=3137 igt_id=igt3137-16 327 328 L T
language: German (deu)
line=327 tag=L:            (ii) Die lokale Domäne für einen Ausdruck A ist der minimale CFC, der sämtliche Lizensierer von A enthält.
line=328 tag=T:                 `The local domain for an expression A is the minimal CFC that contains all licensors of A.'

doc_id=3137 igt_id=igt3137-17 329 330 L+SY T
language: German (deu)
line=329 tag=L+SY:            (iii) Domänen abschließende Elemente sind: I und Elemente, welche die [Spec, DP]-Position realisieren.
line=330 tag=T:                  `Domain-closing elements are: I and those elements that realize the [Spec, DP]-position.'

doc_id=3137 igt_id=igt3137-18 331 334 L L T T
language: German (deu)
line=331 tag=L:            (iv) Unter dem Begriff `SUBJEKT' werden jene syntaktischen Repräsentanten einer externen Argumentstelle, welche in
line=332 tag=L:                 eine Bindungsbeziehung mit einer DP eintreten können, und Domänen abschließende Elemente zusammengefasst.
line=333 tag=T:                 `The cover term `SUBJECT' stands for domain-closing elements and those syntactic representatives of an external
line=334 tag=T:                 position which can enter into a binding relationship with a DP.'

doc_id=3142 igt_id=igt3142-199 7776 7779 L G T T
language: German (deu)
line=7776 tag=L:           (i)    Ein CFC ist die minimale abschließende Kategorie, in der sämtliche Elemente, die durch einen
line=7777 tag=G:                  gegebenen lexikalischen Kopf eine Projektionslizenz erhalten, realisiert sind.
line=7778 tag=T:                  `A CFC is the minimal domain-closing category in which all the elements that get a license to
line=7779 tag=T:                  project from a given lexical head are realized.'

doc_id=3142 igt_id=igt3142-200 7780 7782 L L T
language: German (deu)
line=7780 tag=L:           (ii) Die lokale Domäne für einen Ausdruck A ist der minimale CFC, der sämtliche Lizensierer von A
line=7781 tag=L:                enthält.
line=7782 tag=T:                `The local domain for an expression A is the minimal CFC that contains all licensors of A.'

doc_id=3142 igt_id=igt3142-201 7783 7785 L L T
language: German (deu)
line=7783 tag=L:           (iii) Domänen abschließende Elemente sind: I und Elemente, welche die [Spec, DP]-Position
line=7784 tag=L:                 realisieren.
line=7785 tag=T:                 `Domain-closing elements are: I and those elements that realize the [Spec, DP]-position.'

doc_id=3142 igt_id=igt3142-202 7786 7790 L L L T T
language: German (deu)
line=7786 tag=L:           (iv) Unter dem Begriff `SUBJEKT' werden jene syntaktischen Repräsentanten einer externen
line=7787 tag=L:                Argumentstelle, welche in eine Bindungsbeziehung mit einer DP eintreten können, und Domänen
line=7788 tag=L:                abschließende Elemente zusammengefasst.
line=7789 tag=T:                `The cover term `SUBJECT' stands for domain-closing elements and those syntactic
line=7790 tag=T:                representatives of an external position which can enter into a binding relationship with a DP.'

language: German (deu)
line=299 tag=L:          c. dass Peter das Buch gelesen haben wird.
line=300 tag=G:             that Peter the book read    have will.
line=301 tag=B:
line=302 tag=M:                                    TüBa-D   /S (spoken):    TüBa-D   /Z (written):
line=303 tag=M:                                    counts    percentage     counts    percentage
line=304 tag=M:                   nominal head     355       31.0%          458       69.3%
line=305 tag=M:        C-Feld
line=306 tag=M:                   any head         718       21.3%          803       68.0%
line=307 tag=M:                   nominal head     790       69.0%          203       30.7%
line=308 tag=M:        Vorfeld
line=309 tag=M:                   any head         2648      78.7%          378       32.0%
line=310 tag=M:
line=311 tag=M:           Table 3: Distribution of nominal phrases in Vorfeld and C-Feld.
line=312 tag=B:
line=313 tag=B:
line=314 tag=B:
line=315 tag=T:            '... that Peter will have read the book.'

doc_id=3150 igt_id=igt3150-8 421 476 L G L G L G B M B B B B M B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B B M M M B M M M B B B M M M M B T T T
language: German (deu)
line=421 tag=L:    (6) Der Nordwest-Zeitung sagte Glogowski, ausgenommen werden von der
line=422 tag=G:        To the Nordwest-Zeitung said Glogowski, exempted          be     of the
line=423 tag=L:        neuen Steuer- und Sozialabgabenpflicht sollten Zeitungsträger,
line=424 tag=G:        new tax       and social contributions should newspaper carriers,
line=425 tag=L:        Chorleiter oder Übungsleiter in Sportvereinen.

doc_id=3406 igt_id=igt3406-78 3285 3291 L L L L T T T
language: German (deu)
line=3285 tag=L:              Der Insektenfreund Mark Möller sammelt verschiedenste Arten von Fliegen.
line=3286 tag=L:              Er bekommt ständig neue Fliegenexemplare von Freunden und Bekannten.
line=3287 tag=L:              Möller klebt alle toten Fliegen in sein Insektenbuch ein.
line=3288 tag=L:              Gerade hat er wieder eine neue Seite in seinem Buch befliegt/beflogen.
line=3289 tag=T:              (`The insect lover Marc Miller collects different kinds of flies. He constantly
line=3290 tag=T:              gets more flies from friends. Miller puts all dead flies in his books of insects.

line=1026 tag=M:  16
line=1027 tag=M:     For a motivation see Alexiadou & Anagnostopoulou (2001).
line=1028 tag=M:  17
line=1029 tag=M:     An XP should be interpreted as focussed, topicalised, specific, etc. only as a result of checking some formal
line=1030 tag=M:  feature, i.e. as a by-product of a narrow syntactic operation.
line=1031 tag=M:  18
line=1032 tag=M:     "Optional operations can apply only if they have an effect on outcome: in the present case, v* may be assigned
line=1033 tag=M:  an EPP-feature to permit successive cyclic A'-movement or INT (under OS)." (Chomsky 1999, p. 28)
line=1034 tag=B:
line=1035 tag=M:                                                        29

doc_id=3626 igt_id=igt3626-142 5407 5422 L+CR L+CR B B M M M M M M M B M B G T
language: German (deu)
line=5407 tag=L+CR:                             ... daß pro ein Apfel gegessen wurde.132
line=5408 tag=L+CR:                    b.
line=5409 tag=B:
line=5410 tag=B:
line=5411 tag=M:  131
line=5412 tag=M:      Vikner's (1995, p. 175) arguments against Partitive Case in German, however, fail in the clause structure I
line=5413 tag=M:  propose because there the subject is not vP-internal, or more precisely it is contained in the vP that has moved to
line=5414 tag=M:  SpecTP, and is therefore not predicted to carry anything but Nominative Case.
line=5415 tag=M:  132
line=5416 tag=M:      In fact, if nicht marked the left edge of vP in German as well (although I have a hunch that it is VP-internal in
line=5417 tag=M:  German), (i) would argue against Vikner's assumption.
line=5418 tag=B:
line=5419 tag=M:                                                    129
line=5420 tag=B:
line=5421 tag=G:                        ... that pro an apple eaten       was
line=5422 tag=T:                        "... that an apple was eaten."

line=358 tag=L:  (9)   a.   Denn ein Teil dieser Erkenntnisse, die mathematischen, ist im alten
line=359 tag=L:             Besitze der Zuverlässigkeit, und gibt dadurch eine günstige Erwartung
line=360 tag=L:             auch für andere, ob diese gleich von ganz verschiedener Natur sein

line=366 tag=T:             possessed reliability, and by means of this it provides a favorable

line=368 tag=T:             nature. Besides, if one has left the sphere of experience, one is certain not

doc_id=4012 igt_id=igt4012-14 371 387 L L L L L L+SY G+SY L G T T T T T T T+AC C
language: German (deu)
line=371 tag=L:        b.   Der folgende Ausschnitt aus dem Interview mit einem freien
line=372 tag=L:             Drehbuchautor verweist auf diese "Einsamkeit des Respondenten": Wie
line=373 tag=L:             war das für dich, diese Fragen? (lange Pause) "Ja, ich meine, es ist
line=374 tag=L:             interessant. Ich denke, ich werde selten so mal gefragt und hab die
line=375 tag=L:             Möglichkeit, mich dazu zu äusern, unwidersprochen."
line=376 tag=L+SY:             ____ Nicht unterbrochen und ____ nicht widersprochen zu werden
line=377 tag=G+SY:             PRO.NOM not interrupted and PRO.DAT not contradicted to become.INF
line=378 tag=L:             bedeutet in diesem Falle auch, kaum eine Reaktion zu erhalten.
line=379 tag=G:             means in this case also hardly a reaction to receive
line=380 tag=T:             `The following section from an interview with a freelance scriptwriter
line=381 tag=T:             points out this "solitude of the respondent": How do you feel about
line=382 tag=T:             getting questions of this sort? (a long silence) "Well, I guess it's
line=383 tag=T:             interesting. I'm thinking that I hardly ever get questions like these and
line=384 tag=T:             have the opportunity to express myself about these issues, unchallenged. "
line=385 tag=T:             Being neither interrupted nor challenged means in this case that one
line=386 tag=T+AC:             hardly gets any reactions at all.' (www.qualitative-research.net/
line=387 tag=C:                                               fqs-texte/3-02/3-02schneider-d.htm, 2002)

doc_id=4012 igt_id=igt4012-15 388 411 L L L L L L L+SY G+SY L G L G B M B B T T T T T T T T+AC
language: German (deu)
line=388 tag=L:        c.   Die Betroffenen bauen fast immer ein Vertrauensverhältnis zu ihren
line=389 tag=L:             Betreuern auf. Potenzielle Täter nutzen das freundschaftliche Verhältnis
line=390 tag=L:             häufig aus, um gezielt die Bedürfnisse des behinderten Menschen
line=391 tag=L:             auszuforschen. Je größer die Abhängigkeit, umso größer ist die
line=392 tag=L:             Gefährdung. Wie soll man Berührungen auch vermeiden, wenn auch die
line=393 tag=L:             intimsten Handlungen nicht alleine bewerkstelligt werden können?
line=394 tag=L+SY:             Ein Recht für geistig wie körperlich behinderte Frauen, ____ nur von

line=406 tag=T:             relationship with the specific aim to learn about the needs of the disabled
line=407 tag=T:             person. The greater the dependency, the greater the threat. How is one

doc_id=4017 igt_id=igt4017-90 1474 1490 L L L L L L L+SY L L T T T T T T T T+AC
language: German (deu)
line=1474 tag=L:           Shermer deutete auf die Rohre in einem Brause-Raum im Mauthausen Lager hin,
line=1475 tag=L:           das Touristen als eine Hinrichtungs-"Gaskammer" vorgeführt wird. Indem er
line=1476 tag=L:           behauptete, daß durch diese Rohre Dampf geleitet wurde, um den Raum zu heizen,
line=1477 tag=L:           warf er die Frage auf: "Was kann es anderes (anderes als Tötungsabsichten)
line=1478 tag=L:           bedeuten? Warum würden Sie ein Brausebad wärmen wollen?" Nun, wie wäre es
line=1479 tag=L:           damit, um vielleicht jemanden, der sich duschen wollte, davor zu bewahren, kalt zu
line=1480 tag=L+SY:           ___ werden oder weil derjenige, der die Installationen anbrachte, sich nicht um
line=1481 tag=L:           Ästhetik kümmerte und die Rohre sichtbar ließ oder unzählige andere vernünftige
line=1482 tag=L:           Gründe.
line=1483 tag=T:           'Shermer pointed at the pipe in a shower room in the Mauthausen camp, which is
line=1484 tag=T:           presented to tourists as an execution 'gas chamber'. Claiming that steam was lead
line=1485 tag=T:           through this pipe in order to heat up the room, he raised the question: 'What else
line=1486 tag=T:           can it mean (than an intention to kill)? Why would you want to warm up a shower
line=1487 tag=T:           cabin?' Well, how about maybe in order to prevent somebody who would like to
line=1488 tag=T:           take a shower from freezing, or because the person who fitted the installation did
line=1489 tag=T:           not care about aesthetics and let the pipeline be visible, or countless other sensible
line=1490 tag=T+AC:           reasons.'               (http://www.zundelsite.org/german/artikel/RevDeb.html)

doc_id=4020 igt_id=igt4020-77 1733 1752 L G L+AL B B B M M B B M M M M M B M B L+AL T
language: German (deu)
line=1733 tag=L:  (8)     a. Der Wert hat sich mehr denn verdoppelt.
line=1734 tag=G:              the value has self mehr denn doubled
line=1735 tag=L+AL:          b. weil sich der Wert mehr denn verdoppelt hat / verdoppelte
line=1736 tag=B:
line=1737 tag=B:
line=1738 tag=B:
line=1739 tag=M:      In order to prevent redundancy I outline the patterns displayed in examples (6) ­ (13). The
line=1740 tag=M:  1
line=1741 tag=B:
line=1742 tag=B:
line=1743 tag=M:      a. example with perfect tense in main clause shape is glossed. The b. example in each
line=1744 tag=M:      block is not. It has subordinate shape with perfect and simple past tense separated by `/'.
line=1745 tag=M:      The c. example, which is always ungrammatical, is an attempt to raise the simple past tense
line=1746 tag=M:      verb to the V2 position. A tentative translation follows. Since in German simple past and
line=1747 tag=M:      perfect tense can be used synonymously, one translation is sufficient.
line=1748 tag=B:
line=1749 tag=M:  56                                                                       André Meinunger
line=1750 tag=B:
line=1751 tag=L+AL:           c. *Der Wert verdopplete sich mehr denn.
line=1752 tag=T:               `The value more than merely doubled.'

line=3024 tag=L+CR:    (61) Denn ein Teil dieser Erkenntnisse, die mathematischen, ist im alten Besitze der Zuverlassigkeit, und
line=3025 tag=L+CR:                                                                                                      ¨
line=3026 tag=L+CR:         gibt dadurch eine gunstige Erwartung auch fur andere, ob diese gleich von ganz verschiedener Natur
line=3027 tag=L+CR:                               ¨                          ¨
line=3028 tag=L+CR:                         ¨
line=3029 tag=L+CR:         sein mogen. Uberdem, wenn man uber den Kreis der Erfahrung hinaus ist, so ist man sicher, durch
line=3030 tag=L+CR:                  ¨                            ¨
line=3031 tag=L:         Erfahrung nicht widersprochen zu werden. Der Reiz, seine Erkenntnisse zu erweitern, ist so groß,
line=3032 tag=L+CR:         daß man nur durch einen klaren Widerspruch, auf den man stoßt, in seinem Fortschritte aufgehalten
line=3033 tag=L+CR:                                                                            ¨
line=3034 tag=L:         werden kann.
line=3035 tag=T:             `Because a part of this knowledge, the mathematical one, has always possessed reliability, and by
line=3036 tag=T:             means of this it provides a favorable expectation for others, even though these may be of a quite
line=3037 tag=T:             different nature. Besides, if one is beyond the sphere of experience, one can be certain not to be
line=3038 tag=T:             contradicted by experience. The incentive to expand one's knowledge is so great that one can
line=3039 tag=T:             only be stopped in one's progress by a clear contradiction which one comes up against.'

line=161 tag=B:
line=162 tag=M:  Sigurðsson). Many thanks to our informants: Eiríkur Rögnvaldsson, Gunnar Hrafn Hrafnbjargarson, Höskuldur
line=163 tag=M:  Thráinsson, Jóhanna Barðdal, Jóhannes Gísli Jónsson, Jón Friðjónsson, Thórhallur Eythórsson, and Teodóra
line=164 tag=M:  Torfadóttir. In addition, Gunnar Hrafn, Jóhanna, Thórhallur, Teodóra, and Thorbjörg Hróarsdóttir, kindly filled in
line=165 tag=M:  for us the 1990 survey on the simplex construction.
line=166 tag=M:  3
line=167 tag=M:      However, `Icelandic A', `Icelandic B' and `Icelandic C' are to a certain extent idealizations, since we mostly take
line=168 tag=M:  only the clearest extremes into account. There is considerable variation `in between' these extremes, to which we
line=169 tag=M:  cannot do any justice here, although we mention some of it.
line=170 tag=M:  4
line=171 tag=M:      But on an Icelandic-like variety of Spanish, see Rivero 2004.

line=5579 tag=L+DB:              a. diek      hat ihnj ihmi          gestern geschenkt.                                  What this paradigm is supposed to show is that while the RP may be directly
line=5580 tag=G+DB:                 RP.nom has it.acc him.dat yesterday given                                            selected (as in (71c)), the potential LDed XP may not (cf. the ungrammatical

doc_id=513 igt_id=igt513-13 5581 5582 L+DB G+DB
language: German (deu)
line=5581 tag=L+DB:              b. denj     hat siek       ihmi       gestern geschenkt.                                (71b)), even though the corresponding LD structure is fine (i.e. (71a)). There
line=5582 tag=G+DB:                 RP.acc has she.nom him.dat yesterday given                                           are two immediate replies from the perspective of German for which, after all,

doc_id=513 igt_id=igt513-14 5583 5585 L+DB G+DB T+DB
language: German (deu)
line=5583 tag=L+DB:              c. demi hat siek           ihnj gestern geschenkt.                                      the current proposal is supposed to apply. For one, the equivalent of (71b) is
line=5584 tag=G+DB:                 RP.dat has she.nom it.acc yesterday given                                            grammatical in German. While possibly not acceptable in "standard" German,
line=5585 tag=T+DB:                 `Alex, the car, the mother, yesterday, she gave it to him.'                          it is a construction that is often used colloquially (see also Abraham 2002).

line=676 tag=L:  (37) Was ist ein Ende? Das Ende ist nicht die Stelle, wo das Seil aufhört.
line=677 tag=L:          Sondern in der Seemannssprache heißen alle Leinen und Seile einfach nur
line=678 tag=L:          "Ende". Wenn ein Seemann also sagt: "Bring mir mal das Ende.", dann
line=679 tag=L:          meint er: "Bring mir mal das Seil."
line=680 tag=T:          (What is an "end"? The end is not the point where the rope ends. But in the
line=681 tag=T:          sailer's language, all cords and ropes are simply called "end". When a
line=682 tag=T:          sailer says: "Bring me the end", then he means: "Bring me the rope.")4

doc_id=946 igt_id=igt946-12 315 317 M+CN L G
language: German (deu)
line=315 tag=M+CN:            a. Topicalization of the (restructured) verb cluster (VC)
line=316 tag=L:                Zu schreiben beschlossen hat Karla den Aufsatz.
line=317 tag=G:                To   write     decided      has K.    the article

line=320 tag=G:                What the article concerns so is clear
line=321 tag=L:                warum ihn Karla zu schreiben beschlossen hat.
line=322 tag=G:                why      him K. to write         decided      has

doc_id=946 igt_id=igt946-18 343 345 M+CN L G
language: German (deu)
